indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -Local Government Service Secretariat produce monitoring report on decentralisation process -Local administrative staff trained in decentralisation process -debates organised on constitutional reforms -knowledge products on the code and NMC monitoring function produced and distributed -citizens more aware of about policy options in electoral agendas -increased capacity of EC staff, media and citizen to work together -increase in the rate of women and the vulnerable activity working toward reaching leadership and decision-making positions

baseline.comment: -Tracing mechanisms to assess decentralisation progress are weak -lack of awareness about decentralisation process among local administrative staff -limited public discussions and awareness of CRC recommendations -Breaches of the media code of conduct -Citizens not well informed about electoral agendas -need for more civic education content in the curriculum -level of public confidence in the administration of elections -low representation of women and vulnerable groups in decision making and leadership positions

target.comment: 1) : 40% (NB target will be appropriately adjusted when baseline is determined by GAP Poll ) of voter population have some knowledge in the proposed constitutional amendments recommended by the Constitution Review Report by 2016 (source GAP Poll 2016) 2) 60% of citizens trust the Electoral Commission to deliver on its mandate by the end of 2016 3) National policy on Popular Participation in Local Governance 100% developed and validated by end-2016 4) A Baseline of 76% of citizens who had not contacted any district assembly official in the past 12 months to discuss an important issue by the end of 2014 reduces to 70% by end-2016 5) total of 25,000 citizens participating in nationwide governance assessments by end of 2016 6) Six (6) initiatives established and/or supported to promote womens participation in decision-making processes by 2016 7): Developed baseline on HIV related stigma and discrimination by 2016

actual.comment: The planned activities for the constitutional review could not be implemented as a result of a court injunction that was placed on the process since the last quarter of 2014. The case was determined and dismissed in the October 2015. The Committee has been meeting to plan public sensitization and a referendum. The Electoral Commission (EC) experienced a number of material changes in 2015 creating uncertainty and causing the trust of citizens in the Commission to decrease to 40% (Gap Poll 2015). The most significant change was the retirement of the EC Chairman who had been at the helm for 23 years. There were some public protests prior to the appointment which was finally made midyear. The new Chair who is external to the EC does not have any elections experience at the time of the appointment but is supported by two deputies who although have been with the EC longer are still relatively new to election management. Additionally the ECs image has suffered somehow from many challenges in the aftermath of the 2008 and 2012 presidential elections. The Supreme Court in 2013 and subsequently a reform committee as well as the Inter-party Advisory Committee (IPAC) enumerated over 20 reforms for the institution. Finally the credibility of the Voters Register (VR) in its current state is in doubt. The leading opposition party in Ghana, the NPP has formerly requested for a new register for the 2016 elections on the basis that it is incurably flawed. This claim is resisted by the governing NDC. The EC has endorsed the recommendation to clean the current register by an eminent panel who investigated the positions and evidence presented by all political parties, civil society organizations and citizens in a public forum and its ensuing consultations. The EC recognizing the critical need to reposition the institution and further enhance its credibility, sought support from UNDP. Thus aA five year strategic plan for Electoral Commission to build their capacity to manage free

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -Number and level of consultations on policy formulationss and decision making -Number of citizens participating in local governance assessments (including vulnerable groups) district assembly debates validation workshops through APRM structures. -Increased public confidence in he administration of justice -increased numbers of women and vulnerable groups access the justice system

baseline.comment: -Inadequate engagements between citizens and governance/public institutions -noticeable low levels of citizens response to the Citizens Report Card (11,078 citizens), participation in the district assembly debates (1032) and validation workshop (11968) -Weaknesses in legal framework and institutional capacity hampering the delivery of justice -Paucity of legal professionals in specialised fields

target.comment: 1) Public service integrity programme operational 2) Review and adopt at least one anti-corruption legislation 3) Baseline reduced to 80% 4) 80 MDAs and MMDAs have published Client Charters by 2015 5) 460 cases reported and 400 resolved 6) At least one criminal justice institution operating a functional case management system 7) Baseline reduces to 60%

actual.comment: In 2015, National Anti-Corruption Action Plan (NACAP) implementation began with the finalization of a monitoring and evaluation framework to track progress. A public integrity programme was launched with designated Ethics officers from 35 Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) fully aware of their role in championing public sector ethics and integrity. Over 100 investigators of the Commission for Human Rights and Administrative Justice have improved capacity to investigate breaches of the code of conduct for public officers (Presidents address at NACAP Conference; CHRAJ annual report) To implement UNCAC Ghana review report recommendation, two anti-corruption bills (Witness Protection bill, Conduct of Public Officers Bill) have been drafted while an existing legislation (whistle Blower Act) is being amended, the Conduct of Public Officers Bill and the whistle Blower Act Amendment bill are both at the consideration stage in Parliament, the Witness Protection bill is gone for cabinet approval. These were done through consultations with Parliamentarians, public servants and CSOs. (MoJAGD annual report; CHRAJ annual Report). As a result of the findings of the anti-Corruption baseline survey on the Customs, an integrity Manual and curriculum has been developed for staff training. Lessons learnt on the implementation of Client service charters in the past has been documented through a baseline survey conducted. The findings of this survey will guide the development of a prototype client service chapter for adoption and implementation by all public institutions for improved service delivery Speedy and efficient delivery of administrative justice cases achieved; 196 cases resolved of 236 cases received in 2015. This was possible due to the capacity building of CHRAJ staff on the effective and efficient handling of cases. In order to address comprehensively some of the key findings of the 2012 baseline such as lack of communication and coordination among the justi

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Standards for improved cookstoves available - International impact oriented indicators available in the GEAR toolkit

baseline.comment: - Ghana developed the SE4ALL Action Plan, focused on the promotion of productive uses of energy and access to modern forms of fuels for cooking (e.g. LPG and improved cookstoves) - No technical standards for improved cookstoves available in Ghana - Impact oriented energy access indicators not identified and utilized in energy access measurements in Ghana

target.comment: 1) Technical standards for improved cookstoves gazetted 2) Testing and certification center at TCC fully operational by December 2015 3) Stakeholders educated on the cookstoves standards developed and the benfits of using improved cookstoves over traditional ones. 4) Zero used refrigerators entering Ghana market 5) 15,000 refrigerators exchanged through the rebate scheme

actual.comment:
1, 2 and 3) The standards for improved cookstoves have been drafted by the mirror committee led by Ghana Standards Authority. This is done in parallel with the development of global ISO standards, which is receiving significant contributions from the Ghana Energy Commission. Comments have been received on the draft, however, it has been suggested to hold additional stakeholder consultations (in 2016) in order to receive as many inputs as possible, in particular from those stakeholders (like the manufacturers) who are going to be impacted the most by the enforcement of national standards. The Cookstove Testing and Expertise Laboratory was successfully established at the Technology Consulting Centre (TCC) of the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST) and commissioned in March 2015, and is fully functional. The laboratory is meant not only to test cookstoves (especially to verify compliance with the standards, when published), but also to conduct research to further improve the technology. The management and business processes of the lab are being streamlined to ensure business sustainability. In order to promote awareness on improved cookstoves, radio jingles were developed in 6 different languages, and aired on 45 local and national radio stations. The maiden Renewable Energy Fair was successfully organized by the Energy Commission alongside the West African Clean Environment and Energy Conference. It constituted a platform to discuss the renewable energy sector (policies, challenges, success stories etc.) and to showcase public and private interventions in the sector.
4 and 5) UNDP supported some exit strategies for the Refrigerator Energy Efficiency Project, which ended in 2014. In particular, support was provided to do conduct quarterly compliance monitoring activities to cover all the regions. The main objectives were to check the labels fixed on the refrigerators in the various retail and outlet shops for compliance with the labelling guidel

iati-activity.description: The project will facilitate exchange of renewable energy expertise and technology between China and Ghana, building on Chinas unique development experience.

iati-activity.title: Renewable Energy, China/GH sou
iati-activity.description: The project will facilitate exchange of renewable energy expertise and technology between China and Ghana, building on Chinas unique development experience.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Number of consultative meetings on RE policy and gaps in Ghana held. 2) Report on barriers for RET transfer produced 3) Report on criteria and specifications for selection of 4 RETs 4) number and type of training packages developed 5) number of reports and surveys developed and published; 6) Roadmap launched and disseminated; 7) Documents establishing PMUs and PSCs exist

baseline.comment: 1) Ghana adopted the Renewable Energy Act in 2011, but there is no master plan to implement it. 2) Barriers to effective transfer of Renewable Energy existed. 3) Currently, there is no demonstration site set up for Renewable Energy Technology Transfer (RETT) 4) There is no mechanism for up-scaling of RETs for Public-Private actors established, and capacity building required 5) The UNDP South-South Cooperation Framework 6) There is no existing mechanism for promoting Renewable Energy Technology Transfe 7) PMUs and PSCs havent been established.

target.comment: 1) Review of Chinese and Ghanaian Renewable Energy Policies conducted. 2) Report on barriers completed 3) Renewable Energy Master Plan developed 4) Stakeholder list developed; Project organization established; regular meetings held

actual.comment:
1) A review of Ghanaian policies on renewable energy was conducted to identify gaps to address and opportunities to take in order to boost the sector and achieve the policy target of 10% of renewable energy (excluding large hydro) in the electricity generation mix by 2020. The review made concrete recommendations that will officially be presented to the Ministry of Power. These were also based on the experience from China, whose plans, regulations, strategies and incentives have made the country one of the largest producers of renewable energy. This review was conducted in a consultative manner (2 stakeholder workshops with 96 participants; 4 focus group discussions with specific stakeholder groups).
2) A study was conducted to identify barriers to renewable energy technology transfer RETT) to Ghana, and a road map developed to remove them. This was done by engaging several stakeholders at different levels. The study reviewed current technology transfer regulations; provided history of RETT in Ghana; identified specific political, economic/financial, market, institutional, awareness/information, technical, human skills, legal/regulatory, socio-cultural, and network barriers to RETT; detailed road map to address these challenges.
3) The main output for 2015 was the development of the Renewable Energy Master Plan. However, this was put on hold until 2016, as there was the need to complete other studies (like the policy review and barrier analysis mentioned above) and other government strategies (like the Strategic National Energy Plan) in order to fully understand the scope and content of the Master Plan. Preliminary activities have started, such as the development of a baseline for the Plan.
4) The Energy Commission initiated partnerships with Ghanaian research institutions to get technical support throughout project implementation, especially for the demonstration sites that will be created. These institutions will be paired with Chinese research institutions, in

baseline.comment: Disaster preparedness and response plans with WASH components at the regional and districts levels not available ( 2014)

target.comment: 1) Establish and ensure the functionality of the project management unit. 2) Provide inputs into the baseline studies 3) Complete development of terms of reference for the Disaster Preparedness and Response Action Plan (DPR)

actual.comment: 1. Project Management Unit has been established and functioning 2. Baseline studies have been completed in the 24 Disaster Prone Communities. 3. Terms of Reference for Disaster Preparedness and Response Action Plan has been completed and an individual consultant procured . An Inception report for the disaster preparedness and response action plans in 24 districts of the Northern Region has been submitted by the consultant.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Levels of public trust in political parties (source: Afrobarometer/GaP Poll) 2) % of female party members willing to contest for leadership positions 3)Levels of public trust in the Electoral Commission (source: GaP Poll) 4) # of IPAC meetings held in election year 5) Number of polling station results submitted to J-PERM within 48 hrs of the close of poll

baseline.comment: 1) 50.5% of Ghanaians trusted political parties somewhat or a lot in 2012. 3) 57% of Ghanaians trust the Electoral Commission somewhat or a lot in 2014 to deliver on its mandate 4) 2 meetings held in 2012 5) 19,000 polling station results submitted in 2012

target.comment: 1) Gender Policies and strategies in women participation in political parties placed 2) International Best practices in internal political parties 3) Support main political parties to conduct a baseline and develop membership database 4) Relaunch the Project to gain traction and serve as resource mobilization tool 5) Participate in International best practice meeting and recommend solutions for local adoption

actual.comment: Consensus on issues of common concern among five major political parties has been built through an Inter-Party Platform established with support from UNDP as part of its Joint Party Support and Strengthening (J-PASS) project. Knowledge of 10 representatives (50% female) were improved to understand their commitment in enhancing womens participation in political parties through their participation in an African High Level Dialogue on Democracy, Governance and Human Rights held in Kigali, Rwanda. Three studies on documenting best practices for the development of gender policies, membership data base and inter party communication policies for political parties have been commissioned with the draft reports ready for validation.

iati-activity.description: To support the Government of Ghana in strengthening their national capacities to effectively and efficiently plan for, access, manage, deploy and monitor climate financing in particular through the GCF once it is fully operational.

iati-activity.title: GCF Readiness Programme in Gh
iati-activity.description: To support the Government of Ghana in strengthening their national capacities to effectively and efficiently plan for, access, manage, deploy and monitor climate financing in particular through the GCF once it is fully operational

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Number of national entities identified and assessed for National Implementing Entities (NIE) potential - Number of workshops held to strengthen climate change coordination - Reconstitution of the NCCC - Number of tools developed for economic and budget analysis of climate finance - Number of online knowledge management platforms to support project pipelines - Number of workshops to train stakeholders on prioritising procedures - Number of tools developed to assess and design climate interventions - Number of MRV templates developed

baseline.comment: - Ghanaian public and private entities not assessed for existing fiduciary governance capacity - No workshops held to strengthen coordination - National Climate Change Committee is not currently active - No tools developed for climate finance related economic and budget analysis - No online knowledge management platform to support project pipelines - No trainings for stakeholders on prioritising interventions - No tools developed to assess and design climate interventions - No MRV templates or guidance

target.comment: 1. Mapping and assessment of Ghanaian national public or private entities that are eligible to access funds from the GCF complete 2. Ghanas climate change coordination across national and sub-national levels strengthened 3. Strengthening of climate change regulations, policies, plans and budgeting supported 4. Stakeholder access to information and knowledge products on climate change increased 5. Guidelines and procedures developed for prioritizing climate change needs and interventions 6. Market based and value chain business model tools developed to assess, design and measure climate change interventions, including Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA) and project checklists and safeguards 7. Monitoring and evaluation (MRV) templates and guidance developed

actual.comment:
The GCF readiness programme started implementation from June 2015 with the inception workshop, as the fund was only received to the country office in May. Following the inception, a half-day workshop was organized in August with the support from the GCF secretariat to increase stakeholders knowledge on the National Implementing Entities (NIEs) accreditation requirement and process. In November, National Designated Authority (NDA) for GCF, Real Sector Division of Ministry of Finance, advertised a call for application to identify potential NIEs candidates in Ghana. Capacity assessment of the identified entities will be conducted as a next step.
In order to strengthen climate change coordination, the project supported Ministry of Environment, Science, Technology, and Innovation (MESTI) to organize the National Climate Change Steering Committee. The committee reviewed Ghanas progress in the preparation of Intended Nationally Determined Contributions to UNFCCC, and discussed the formation of working groups under the committee including climate finance working group.
The consultants were engaged to 1) develop the operational manual for NDA and 2) develop the climate change project prioritization tool. The prioritization tool will be used by national stakeholders to identify and prioritize the areas for GCF proposal development. Further, building up from the outcome of the Climate Public Expenditure and Institutional Review conducted by Ministry of Finance earlier this year, the project will support the development of the climate change budget and finance tracking tool.

iati-activity.title: Advocacy & Cap Building on DRR
iati-activity.description: Advocacy and capacity building for disaster risk reduction and preparedness in Ghana

document-link.title: GFDRR Project Proposal 8th draft to WB 4feb14

iati-activity.title: Advocacy & Cap Building on DRR
iati-activity.description: Advocacy and capacity building for disaster risk reduction and preparedness in Ghana

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Report covering the celebration of the International Day for DRR 2) Minutes and approved programme for the annual review meeting of the national platform 3) Draft and final awareness creation materials submitted 4) Core Training Agenda developed 5) Report on regional and district simulation exercises organised.

baseline.comment: 1) The is annual event, and has been celebrated in previous year including 2014 2) National platform already exist 3) There are existing materials but need to be updated 4) There is existing literature and different training programmes with various academic and learning institutions 5) Similar prepared and awareness stimulation exercise are in place

target.comment: 1) Organize high level, public events, in particular within the context of the International Day for DRR, to raise awareness on specific topics and issues related to DRR in Ghana. 2) Support awareness and advocacy activities organized by the National Platform for DRR 3) Develop awareness creation material for disaster risk reduction and prevention. 4) Develop a core training agenda addressing disaster risk reduction and management for government cadres from various administrative levels. 5) Organize 1 regional and 1 district simulation exercises to strengthen disaster preparedness.

actual.comment:
1) Two main events were organized to sensitize on Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR). The International Day for Disaster Reduction was celebrated in a disaster prone community called Anyamam, with focus on the importance of indigenous and traditional knowledge. In addition, radio discussions were held and a social media campaign was carried out around this theme. The second event is the annual meeting of the National Platform on DRR, which brought together the main stakeholders involved in disaster management. It was an opportunity to take stock of 2015 activities on DRR both at the regional and national levels, and to strategize on 2016 advocacy activities in line with the new Sendai Framework for Action.
4) A stock-tacking exercise was conducted to map out existing DRR programmes or trainings in tertiary institutions and identify gaps. On the basis of this, a core training agenda addressing disaster risk reduction and management for government cadres from various administrative levels was developed and validated by stakeholders from tertiary education institutions. The actual programs will be developed and carried out in 2016.
5) A regional simulation exercise was organized in the Upper West Region, using floods as disaster scenario. The aim was to assess the preparedness and response capability of major stakeholders in disaster risk management, test effectiveness of the existing contingency plans, and evaluate the co-ordination level among these stakeholders. About 230 participants from national, regional, and district level institutions participated. A debriefing session with 70 participants was held to discuss main issues and recommendations.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) No stock out of reagents and supplies for testing EVD; # of temperature screening equipment installed 2) Number of personnel trained; Number of situation reports expected generated; Number of protective and preventive items provided; Number of immigration officers trained; Number of entry/exit sites that conduct EBV surveillance; Childhood disease management protocol available; Number of community-based surveillance volunteers trained

baseline.comment:
The Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) outbreak was first reported to WHO in March 2014. As at 29 October 2014, about 14,000 cases and nearly 5,000 deaths have been recorded mainly from the three most affected countries, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.
Ghana is considered as being at high risk of importation of EVD in view of a combination of varied number of factors which have the potential to trigger an outbreak which will have a devastating impact on health, economic, social, security and overall development of the country. Some of these factors include

actual.comment: Though no Ebola case has been registered in Ghana, the UN system under and the UN Coordination framework continuous to coordinate and liaise with development partners and government to keep the country in readiness and out of risk.
